body:
According to http://vim.1045645.n5.nabble.com/Add-milliseconds-to-strftime-td5724772.html it seems like there's not way to get this time resolution on the (Neo)Vim side.

Related: https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/1404

I would like to use this to distinguish if an async process should be started, but without calling it (Python) directly to check the time(out).

comment_data.body:
https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/839  `reltime()` has microsecond-accuracy (on all platforms, and monotonic where possible). It can be formatted with `reltimestr()`. 

This (cross-platform micros-precision with monotonicity where available) is a feature that distinguishes nvim from vim.
Yes, for sure. I had a hard time finding it myself.

As per https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/5301 `reltime()` is not really the current time though.
My use case is a log prefix with Neomake, where a more granular resolution than seconds is needed, but `reltime()` could be used after all.
This ia very useful for writting log, hepo it can be implemented soon. :)
You can use `vim.loop.now()` in Lua (or `luaeval('vim.loop.now()')` from Vim script). `vim.loop.hrtime()` provides sub-millisecond granularity.
@gpanders thanks, but if I want to get time string like `21:58:30`, I can use `strftime('%H:%M:%S')`, but how to get `21:58:30:768`
It seems `uv.now()` can start counting at any arbitrary millisecond, so this is not really accurate.

hmm, the format should be changed, because somtimes I got:

```
[ SpaceVim ] [22:31:51:864] [ Info  ] init spacevim root dir:C:/Users/wsdjeg/.SpaceVim/
[ SpaceVim ] [22:31:51:14] [ Info  ] Startup with no argv, current dir is used: ~\.SpaceVim
```

I think it should be:

```
[ SpaceVim ] [22:31:51:864] [ Info  ] init spacevim root dir:C:/Users/wsdjeg/.SpaceVim/
[ SpaceVim ] [22:31:51:014] [ Info  ] Startup with no argv, current dir is used: ~\.SpaceVim
```


--------------



Wang Shidong



>It seems `uv.now()` can start counting at any arbitrary millisecond, so this is not really accurate.



>



>--

>Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub:



>https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/4433#issuecomment-968076990
Ok, thanks, the comment has been edited, but no email notification, sorry.

> It seems `uv.now()` can start counting at any arbitrary millisecond, so this is not really accurate.

yeah, please see these log: line 2 and line 3

```
[ SpaceVim ] [22:36:12:943] [ Info  ] global_dir is: C:/Users/wsdjeg/.SpaceVim.d/
[ SpaceVim ] [22:36:12:943] [ Info  ] start to apply config [glob]
[ SpaceVim ] [22:36:12:025] [ Info  ] SpaceVim server startup at:\\.\pipe\spacevim-nvim-server
[ SpaceVim ] [22:36:12:147] [ Info  ] the func has been added to mode:syntax-checking
[ SpaceVim ] [22:36:13:358] [ Info  ] the func has been added to mode:spell-checking
```
AFAIK there is currently no API to get **absolute** (since epoch) time in milliseconds.
libuv added `uv_gettimeofday()` in 1.28.0 ([ref](https://github.com/libuv/libuv/issues/1197)). This is currently accessible in Neovim as `vim.uv.gettimeofday()`.

I believe a solution exists here, so closing this.

If it is not sufficient, then issue can be re-opened.

This example is provided for convenience:

```lua
local get_time = function()
	local second, microsecond = vim.uv.gettimeofday()
	local second_format = os.date("%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S", second)
	local microsecond_format = string.format("%06d", microsecond)
	local time = second_format .. " " .. microsecond_format
	return time
end

local print_time = function()
	print(get_time())
end

-- test:
print_time()
```

title: Provide an API to get current milliseconds
